LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
June 30, 2023
Jill Schreuder
Catholic Charities West Michigan- Benton Harbor
185 E. Main St.102,
Benton Harbor, MI, 49022-4432
Re: License #: CB110403982
Dear Ms. Schreuder:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. No
substantial violations were found.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 204-6992.
Sincerely,
Heather A Reilly, Licensing Consultant
enclosure

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
SPECIAL INVESTIGATION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CB110403982
Licensee Group Organization: Catholic Charities West Michigan
Licensee Designee: Jill Schreuder
Chief Administrator: Jill Schreuder
Agency Name: Catholic Charities West Michigan- Benton
Harbor
Agency Address: 185 E. Main St.102
Benton Harbor, MI 49022-4432
License Status: Regular
License Expiration Date: 10/20/2024
II. METHODOLOGY
Contact Date Contact Method Contact Purpose
6/13/2023 Email Other
6/13/2023 Email Interview
6/13/2023 Email Special Investigation Initiation
6/13/2023 Phone Special Investigation Initiation

6/27/2023 Phone Interview
6/30/2023 Phone Pre-exit with Chief Administrator
1

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster Parent Information
Section (1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all of the following
Description information before the placement or replacement of a child:
(h) Any other known information to enable the foster parent to
provide a stable, safe, and healthy environment for the foster child
and the foster family, including information about siblings who do
not reside in the foster home.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Agency did not provide foster parent with information about child
prior to placement.
Investigation On 6/12/23 it was reported to DCWL that the agency did not
provide Foster Parent with important information about Youth A
prior to placement. Specifically, the foster parent was not informed
Youth A was involved in multiple investigations, including one
case where Youth A was possibly involved in the rape of another
foster child. In addition, Youth A completed a trauma assessment,
which recommended he should not be placed with other children.
As this information was not provided to the foster parent, the youth
was placed in a home with other children and shared a bedroom
with another youth since January 2023. Reportedly, the foster
home is a borrowed bed from another agency. Licensing Worker 1
and Foster Parent indicated they had no knowledge of this youth’s
history when the Borrowed Bed Agreement began. Foster Parent
expressed concern to Complainant about not having this
information, as she has used respite care with Youth A, in a home
with younger children. Had Foster Parent known this history, she
would have made alternative arrangements. Complainant
indicated a Family Team Meeting (FTM) occurred recently to
discuss Youth A’s school concerns. During the FTM no one from
the agency mentioned any safety concerns. However, after the
meeting, the trauma assessment report was reviewed and indicate
Youth A may not be safe in a home with any other children. The
agency knew this information prior to the meeting but did not
discuss it with the team.
Complainant was contacted via email on 6/13/23. Complainant
indicated they did not have a copy of the Trauma Assessment.
However, they provided contact information for those involved in
the case.
On 6/13/23 an attempt was made to contact Chief
Administrator by phone. A follow-up email was sent regarding
2

the allegation and investigation. On 6/13/23 Chief Administrator
responded and provided contact information for Program
Manager, Foster Care Supervisor, and Foster Care Worker 1.
DHHS Monitor was contacted via email on 6/13/23 regarding
the trauma assessment. DHHS Monitor stated they had
reviewed the trauma assessment and did not recall seeing a
recommendation not place Youth A with other children. DHHS
Monitor reported being aware of the incident Complainant alluded
to regarding rape. DHHS Monitor stated there was an allegation
previously, but it was dropped. DHHS Monitor could not recall any
details, as they were not directly involved in the case. It was noted
there was no information about this in MiSACWIS, likely because
the allegation was dismissed. DHHS Monitor also did not recall
any other incidents of inappropriate sexual behavior by Youth A in
any foster homes.
Licensing Supervisor was interviewed by video conference
on 6/13/23. Licensing Supervisor is employed by the agency that
loaned the current foster home to Catholic Charities for the
placement of Youth A. Licensing Supervisor was not directly
involved with placement, as Licensing Worker 2 was assigned to
the home at that time. Licensing Supervisor indicated that they
strive to be as open and honest with foster parents as possible. It
is in their agency’s best interest to do so, as it helps them assist
the foster parents and maintain placements. Regarding the
allegation, their agency was not informed by Catholic Charities
that Youth A had a history of sexually acting out, or a trauma
assessment that recommended placements without other children.
However, Licensing Supervisor indicated Licensing Worker 1
would have more knowledge.
Licensing Worker 1 was interviewed by video conference on
6/13/23. Licensing Worker 1 is assigned to the foster parent who
currently has placement of Youth A. Licensing Worker 1
acknowledged the placement request did not have much
information on it. However, Licensing Worker 1 indicated she was
not assigned to the home or part of this placement in January
2023. Licensing Worker 1 provided contact information for the
previously assigned person, Licensing Worker 2. Licensing
Worker 1 stated she had some emails between Licensing Worker
2 and Foster Care Worker 2 from Catholic Charities, which had
more details about the information provided to their agency and
Foster Parent before the borrowed bed agreement began. Foster
Parent asked Foster Care Worker 2 several questions prior to
placement. Since placement, Foster Parent has had frequent
3

contact with Youth A’s Court Appointed Special Advocate (CASA).
Licensing Worker 1 also has a safety plan in place with Foster
Parent currently, due to the allegations in this investigation.
Licensing Worker 2 was interviewed via Teams on 6/14/23.
Licensing Worker 2 assisted with placement of Youth A into his
current foster home, as a borrowed bed placement. Licensing
Worker 2 confirmed she emailed with Foster Parent and Foster
Care Worker 2 from Catholic Charities about the placement at the
time. Foster Parent had a lot of questions, as it was understood
that Youth A would be sharing a bedroom with another, older,
youth. Regarding the current allegation, Licensing Worker 2 stated
Foster Parent would not have accepted placement if they had any
knowledge of sexual behavior. At the time of placement there was
not any sort of sexual behaviors disclosed for Youth A.
Licensing Worker 3 was contacted by email on 6/13/23.
Licensing Worker 3 is from another agency, which previously
loaned a home to Catholic Charities for placement of Youth A from
6/14/21- 9/2/21. An allegation on 6/16/21 indicated some
sexualized behavior between Youth A and another youth in that
foster home. Children’s Services declined to investigate, the
agency did not complete a special evaluation and it appeared law
enforcement was not involved. As there was little information on
file, Licensing Worker 3 was asked if she had any knowledge
about the incident. Licensing Worker 3 stated she could not recall
what the specific allegation was. However, the agency did not
investigate as there was not a rule violation alleged.
CASA was interviewed by phone on 6/15/23. CASA reported
being involved with the case since July 2022. When asked about
knowledge of any sexual incidents regarding Youth A and another
foster child, CASA reported being informed of some incidents in
the past, but not having specific information. On 1/11/23 CASA
spoke with Foster Parent, who seemed to not know about these
incidents. CASA was informed DCWL was unable to locate
documentation to verify these sexual incidents occurred. CASA
stated they were aware of an incident between Youth A and
another child in a foster home sometime between August and
December 2021. However, they did not know of any detail other
than an investigation determined the allegations were unfounded
and there were no charges. CASA reported they did not have any
documentation regarding this. CASA denied discussing this with
the Foster Parent but encouraged the agency to disclose the
information. Regarding the trauma assessment, CASA stated they
were aware the report did not specifically indicate Youth A should
4

not be placed with other children. However, CASA believed that
recommendation was made in a safety plan from the 2021
investigation. There was no documentation available to verify this.
Foster Care Supervisor was scheduled for a video conference
interview on 6/20/23. The interview was confirmed on 6/14/23.
However, Foster Care Supervisor resigned her position prior to
the interview and did not wish to reschedule.
Program Manager was interviewed on 6/21/23 via video
conference. Program Manager reported the previous foster care
worker (Foster Care Worker 2), who participated in placement of
Youth A, is currently on a medical leave and unavailable. Program
Manager admitted she did not have much first-hand knowledge of
the placement. However, she recalled speaking with Foster Care
Supervisor about the trauma assessment. The assessment was
completed as the agency was considering placing Youth A with
fictive-kin and felt therapy would be helpful with that relationship.
However, the fictive-kin placement fell through as they were not
an appropriate caregiver. A placement request form was sent
state-wide. Licensing Worker 2 reached out with a potentially
interested foster parent. Licensing Worker 2, Foster Parent, and
Foster Care Worker 2 emailed some questions back and forth
prior to accepting placement. Regarding the indication that Youth
A was accused of rape, Program Manager stated that it was her
understanding the case was investigated and had no findings.
However, she was not involved in the investigation and did not
have documentation. The Program Manager stated that in the
agency’s opinion, as the matter was unsubstantiated, there was
not anything to tell a potential foster parent. There was not any
other information available to the agency that Youth A had been
sexually inappropriate. In addition, the trauma assessment did not
recommend that Youth A should not be placed with other children.
Therefore, the agency believed unfounded allegations were not
required to be shared with potential placement providers. Program
Manager stated if they were aware of a recommendation not to
place with other children, or any substantiated incidents of sexual
behavior, they would have shared the information and tried to
safety plan around it. Program Manager noted there were some
concerns with the accuracy of the trauma assessment as Youth A
told Foster Care Worker 2, he lied several times during the
assessment. This is a typical behavior for Youth A, as he is angry
with the system and attempting to sabotage things. Which could
also be a reason for him to provide misinformation to Foster
Parent. However, Foster Parent continues to advocate for him and
work with the agency to maintain placement.
5

Foster Care Worker 1 was interviewed by phone on 6/27/23.
Youth A was not assigned to this worker when placement
occurred. Youth A has been assigned to this worker since April
2023. Foster Care Worker 1 stated they were not aware of any
sexual behavior or allegations against Youth A. It was noted on
the trauma assessment that Youth A had some history, but when
Foster Care Supervisor was asked about it, she stated it was an
incident of truth or dare between Youth A and another foster child.
There were no findings from that incident. Foster Care Worker 1
did not recall seeing a recommendation in the trauma assessment
regarding placement with other children. Currently Youth A is
doing well in the home, although he can be anti-social at times.
Foster Parent is very involved and engaged. Foster Parent cares
very much about the kids in her home and does a great job getting
them into the right services. Foster Parent calls Foster Care
Worker 1 on a regular basis and informs the agency of any issues
that come up. There have been no concerns about sexually
inappropriate behavior by Youth A in his current foster home.
Documents reviewed:
On 6/12/23 Youth A’s case file was reviewed in MISACWIS:
• Youth A moved to current foster home on 1/5/23.
Placement outline from 1/5/23 did not identify any
immediate concerns, need for increased supervision, or
behavior plan.
• Youth A was placed in a home from 1/7/22 to 4/22/22. No
allegations or special evaluations occurred.
• Youth A was placed in a home from 8/2/21-1/7/22. One
special evaluation was initiated on 12/28/21. It was alleged
Youth A touched another child while sharing a bedroom.
During the special evaluation the child reported that Youth
A did not touch him. The child stated two other children had
touched him in the past. The foster parent stated that the
child was known to bring up things from the past and speak
about them as if they were currently happening. No
violations were found. Children’s Services and Law
Enforcement did not investigate.
• Youth A was placed in a home 6/14/21-9/2/21. No special
evaluations were on file. However, there was a DHHS
intake from 6/16/21, which stated Youth A made sexually
inappropriate comments to another foster child. A safety
plan was implemented. Neither DHHS, Law Enforcement,
nor the agency investigated the allegation.
• Youth A was placed in a home from 5/17/21-6/14/21. No
special evaluations were on file. However, there was an
6

intake with DHHS on 5/22/21 which stated Youth A was at
a respite placement where he (age 12) and a female youth
(age 16) touched one another in a sexual way. DHHS did
not investigate. The agency did not complete a special
evaluation as the respite caregiver was unlicensed. The
matter was referred to Law Enforcement, but reportedly
was closed with no findings.
• Children’s Trauma Assessment Center report dated
7/14/22 indicated the following:
▪ Youth A displayed signs of trauma which
included sexual behaviors not typical for age.
However, this was not further explained.
▪ Recommendations did not state youth should
not be placed with other children.
Emails from December 2022 between Licensing Worker 2, Foster
Care Worker 2, and Foster Parent were reviewed. In summary,
Foster Parent was notified of several needs and behaviors of
Youth A. There was no discussion of a history of sexualized
behavior. Foster Parent was provided with the phone number for
Youth A’s foster parent at the time. It is unknown what they
discussed. However, Foster Parent agreed to placement after they
spoke.
Analysis Based on interviews completed and documents reviewed, there is
insufficient evidence to support the allegation. Contrary to what
Complainant reported, the trauma assessment for Youth A did not
make a recommendation that he should be placed without other
children. In addition, although there were three incidents where
Youth A allegedly displayed sexually inappropriate behavior, none
of the incidents were substantiated. In fact, one incident was
investigated and found to be untrue. One incident was a verbal
remark that was allegedly made and an investigation was
determined to be unnecessary. The third allegation was reviewed
by law enforcement and dismissed. The agency indicated they felt
it was wrong to label Youth A as someone with sexualized
behaviors when there was no evidence to support this. It was
noted that licensing rules do not require agencies to report all prior
unsubstantiated allegations to potential foster parents.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
7

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
_ _______________June 30, 2023______________________
Heather Reilly Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
